articles.headline: New European Bank Chief Takes a Bold Approach
articles.snippet: As Mario Draghi prepares for a meeting of its policy council, analysts are predicting another cut in the bank’s benchmark interest rate.
articles.abstract: As Mario Draghi prepares for a meeting of its policy council, analysts are predicting another cut in the bank’s benchmark interest rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — For someone with a reputation for caution, Mario Draghi is off to an audacious start as president of the European Central Bank.

articles.headline: Obama Strikes Populist Chord With Speech on G.O.P. Turf
articles.snippet: Infusing his speech with the type of language that has emerged in the Occupy protests, President Obama on Tuesday delivered his most pointed appeal yet for using taxes and regulations to level the economic playing field.
articles.abstract: Infusing his speech with the type of language that has emerged in the Occupy protests, President Obama on Tuesday delivered his most pointed appeal yet for using taxes and regulations to level the economic playing field.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSAWATOMIE, Kan. — Laying out a populist argument for his re-election next year, President Obama ventured into the conservative heartland on Tuesday to deliver his most pointed appeal yet for a strong governmental role through tax and regulation to level the economic playing field.

articles.headline: Japan Split on Hope for Vast Radiation Cleanup
articles.snippet: Japan hopes the cleanup near the tsunami-ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant will allow the displaced to return home.
articles.abstract: Japan hopes the cleanup near the tsunami-ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant will allow the displaced to return home.
articles.lead_paragraph: FUTABA, Japan — Futaba is a modern-day ghost town — not a boomtown gone bust, not even entirely a victim of the devastating earthquake and tsunami that leveled other parts of Japan’s northeast coast.

articles.headline: In Iowa, Gingrich Is Gaining Favor, New Poll Shows
articles.snippet: Republican voters in Iowa view Newt Gingrich as more prepared to be president than Mitt Romney, a New York Times/CBS News Poll said.
articles.abstract: Republican voters in Iowa view Newt Gingrich as more prepared to be president than Mitt Romney, a New York Times/CBS News Poll said.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Newt Gingrich enters the final four weeks of campaigning before the Iowa caucuses with Republican voters in the state viewing him as more prepared to be president than Mitt Romney, more attuned to their concerns and just as capable of defeating President Obama, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: Gadgets to Outfit Everyone
articles.snippet: Here’s how you can help make sure those who are lacking the basics, like a smartphone or a laptop, are well dressed for the digital age.
articles.abstract: Here’s how you can help make sure those who are lacking the basics, like a smartphone or a laptop, are well dressed for the digital age.
articles.lead_paragraph: TECHNOLOGY is a bit like clothing. Here’s how: Hundreds of thousands of years ago, a single item of clothing (a well-tailored pelt or loincloth) would probably suffice. Clothing did one thing, provide cover.

articles.headline: Whimsical Texting Icons Get a Shot at Success
articles.snippet: Emoji, the more elaborate cousins of emoticons, are available to in-the-know smartphone owners via apps, but Apple’s update to its iPhone software paves the way for them to go mainstream.
articles.abstract: Emoji, the more elaborate cousins of emoticons, are available to in-the-know smartphone owners via apps, but Apple’s update to its iPhone software paves the way for them to go mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: Say you wanted to invite a friend to happy hour. You could send a simple text message, but that would be boring. Instead, why not send a cartoony picture of two clinking beer mugs?

articles.headline: Pearl Harbor Still a Day for the Ages, but a Memory Almost Gone
articles.snippet: After 70 years, Pearl Harbor survivors, aging and fewer in number, are giving up on major gatherings in the future.
articles.abstract: After 70 years, Pearl Harbor survivors, aging and fewer in number, are giving up on major gatherings in the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — For more than half a century, members of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association gathered here every Dec. 7 to commemorate the attack by the Japanese that drew the United States into World War II. Others stayed closer to home for more intimate regional chapter ceremonies, sharing memories of a day they still remember in searing detail.
